title: Multiplexed evaluation of mouse wound tissue using oligonucleotide barcoding with single-cell RNA sequencing
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Part 1: Tissue harvest
Timing: 1 h
In this section, full-thickness wound tissue is excised and processed into a single cell suspension. Wounds may theoretically be harvested at any time post-surgery, but we have only tested this protocol at timepoints between 2 days and 6 months.
Tissue harvest and processing.
Harvest each wound en bloc with the splinting ring in place (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2277-Fig8.jpg
Figure 8. Wound tissue harvest
(A) The mouse is sacrificed. The adhesive dressing is removed prior to tissue harvest, but the silicone ring is left in place.
(B–D) The region of depilated dorsal skin is harvested using dissecting scissors by separation below the panniculus carnosus to ensure complete thickness.
(E–I) The skin is finely minced to sub-millimeter diameter pieces (E–H) and subjected to enzymatic digestion (I).
(J and K) The resulting suspension is then filtered through a 40 mm nylon mesh.
Harvest the dorsal skin using dissecting scissors by separation below the panniculus carnosus to ensure the complete thickness of the skin is harvested (Figures 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]B–8D).
At this stage, up to one-third of each wound may be set aside and processed separately for histology.
Isolate the remaining wound tissue from any underlying attached hypodermis with a scalpel.
Rinse the resulting skin in cold PBS.
To achieve a cell suspension:
Finely mince the harvested skin using sharp scissors into sub-millimeter diameter pieces (Figures 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]E–8H).
Minced tissue should be roughly 0.5 mm in diameter.
Enzymatically digest the minced skin using Liberase DL (0.5 mg/mL; 10 mL needed per 100 mg of tissue) for 1 h at 37oC (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]I).
Filter the resulting suspension through a 40 mm nylon mesh (Figures 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]J and 8K).
Optional: FACS isolation
Timing: 2 h
This optional step allows for the isolation of cell subsets prior to barcoding.

Optional: FACS isolation.
Isolate cells from single cell suspensions using a pre-specified fluorescence-activated cell sorting (FACS) strategy.
One approach to isolate fibroblasts uses a negative lineage gating strategy, wherein a lineage gate (Lin) for hematopoietic (CD45, Ter-119), endothelial (CD31, Tie2), and epithelial (CD326, CD324) cell markers are used as a negative gate to isolate fibroblasts (Lin-).3[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]
Part 2: Oligonucleotide barcoding
Timing: 1.5 h
This step tags cells from each sample with unique oligonucleotide barcodes to permit their downstream identification.
Hashtag oligonucleotide barcoding.
Preparation of cell suspensions.
Enzymatic digestion may cause a cleavage of tissue-specific epitopes, which may not be applicable to non-wound tissue specimens, resulting in reduced staining with TotalSeq antibodies.
Staining conditions and concentrations should be optimized separately for each tissue type.
Assessment of cell viability.
Perform cell counts using a hemocytometer to ensure accurate assessment of cell viability. An ideal cell viability is ≥ 95%.
Dilute cells in an appropriate volume prior to staining.
Dilute 1 million cells in 49.5 μL of Cell Staining Buffer (pre-made from BioLegend) in 1.5 mL Eppendorf tubes (Figures 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]A and 9B).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2277-Fig9.jpg
Figure 9. Single cell suspension preparation and hashtag oligonucleotide barcoding
(A and B) Prior to staining, cell suspensions are washed, spun down, decanted, diluted to an appropriate volume.
(C and D) Cells are then blocked by incubating with TruStain FcX and tagged using titrated amounts of each TotalSeq hashtag antibodies.
(E–I) Following incubation, the cells are filtered using a pipette tip cell strainer to remove any clumps of cells or debris.
If working with pig or human cells, instead dilute 1 million cells in 45 uL of Cell Staining Buffer.
Note: Staining buffer should be stored at 2°C–8°C, for no longer than 6 months.
Block cells.

Add 5 μL of Human TruStain FcX Fc Blocking reagent or 0.5 μL of TruStain FcX PLUS (anti-mouse CD16/32) antibody.
The final blocking volume should be 50 μL.
Incubate for 10 min at 4°C.
While cells are incubating in Fc Block, proceed to next step.
Prepare antibody pool using titrated amounts (up to 1 μg) of each TotalSeq hashtag antibodies.
If the antibody cocktail volume is less than 50 μL, add Cell Staining Buffer up to 50 μL. Then centrifuge the antibody pool at 14,000 g at −8°C for 10 min before adding to the cell suspension prepared above.
Carefully pipette out the prepared antibody pool, avoiding the bottom of the tube, and add the 50 μL of TotalSeq antibody cocktail to the 50 μL blocked cell suspension (Figures 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]C and 9D).
Incubate the stained suspension for 30 min at 4°C.
Wash the stained suspension (repeat 3 times).
Add 0.5 mL of Cell Staining Buffer and spin at 4°C for 5 min at 500 g.
Carefully remove the supernatant using a pipette.
Following the last wash step.
Resuspend the cells in PBS at a concentration of 500–800 cell/μL.
Slowly filter cells through a 40 μm Flowmi Cell Strainer (Figures 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]E–9I).
Verify cell concentration and viability after filtration using a hemocytometer.
Dilute cells in PBS as necessary for appropriate input (10–20 uL) into the 10× Chromium chip for cell capture and subsequent library preparation and sequencing.
Ideal loading volume is 10–20 uL per single well of the 10× Chromium controller.
Manufacturer recommendation for cell number is 10,000 cells, but well-clustered data may be obtained with as few as 1,000 cells per capture.
Our group has found that 10 samples (with unique HTO barcodes) is the ideal number for pooling per 10× well/capture, but we have had success using as few as 2 and as many as 12 pooled samples.
